content.body: apparently shelley's reading comprehension isn't very good. In response to the e-mail where I explain my opinion is irrelevant, she asks for my opinion again
I wonder what her obsession with my opinion today is about, given that she usually thinks my opinion is worthless
Hixie: She needs to know your opinion to make sure she doesn't agree with it? :P
Dashiva: that is sadly far too consistent with previous behaviour
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webapps/2010JanMar/0792.html is interesting
Charles Pritchard, "Advanced Pointer Events: Use Cases"
boblet: hey, I just realized something, which is that I'm not going to be in town on March 27
off-by-one error
the one being one month
I had been thinking we'd talked about April 27, not March 27

have I understood correctly that geopriv would involve the user making privacy choices in the browser chrome but the browsers would be unable to enforce the settings and instead the user would have to trust the site to be benevolent and obedient?
has read www-tag again
MikeSmith: that sucks
hsivonen: yes
bb
boblet: I got a copy of hatano-san's book in the mail today
beefy
550+ pages
MikeSmith: hey, great stuff! He must be relieved
yeah
what’s it like? manual style? explanation? examples? tutorials? practical use cases?
I’m guessing more explaining the spec style with made-up examples
boblet: reference-like
that fits with his site
HTML5 マークアプ ガイドブク
マークアップ, make that
hmm, which sounds very unnatural as a transliteration
man 550 pages. what a machine
seems like it would better just be マーカップ
but oh well
c’mon you know Japanese transliteration ignores naturalness
heh
MikeSmith: i got the html5 books btw
can't read anything but the acronyms, but... :-)
Hixie: ah, cool
Hixie: both the Japanese ones? nice :)
you may have a copy of Hatano-san's book on the way to you as well, not sure
oh, "books"
boblet: yeah
great
yeah we were telling Shiraishi-san he should definitely send you a copy
good to see Japan showing up all the English authors
both Shiraishi-san and Hatano-san are speaking at the Google DevFest event here tomorrow
(or sticking to publisher schedules regardless of the spec ;-) )
Futomi gots his portrait picture on the About the Author page of his book
he looks kind of pissed off, like he's getting ready to kick somebody's ass
was prolly meant to be his serious face (unless writing the book really did take a toll ;-)
I will say that both dudes should have included an prominent URL for an Errata/Updates page
MikeSmith: why?
rofls
there won’t be changes will there?
heh
hopefully the first printing will sell out quickly and they can add a URL to the next print run
definitely seems like it’s the hot topic, so here’s hoping
if we do end up using a non-versioned model in the future, we'll have to find some solution to handle referring to the latesrt version for books and the like
maybe the w3c will just publish annual RECs that include whatever the latest implemented stuff is :-)
wishful thinking ;)
Hixie: Still awake?
gsnedders: here

Hixie: So for Anolis 2 I was planning on changing the way TOC/num worked; Anolis 1 just gets all headers of a certain depth, but I was planning on changing it to only get children of a certain section (specified by class on either the sectioning content or heading content element). That seem reasonable?
come again?
Anolis 1 you just have min-depth and max-depth that controls what is in the TOC, right?
i wasn't aware there was even that much
so long as it grabs all the headers except the ones marked notoc, i'm good
if it does that by looking at the notoc class, or some other magic like determining automatically which should have had notoc, i don't mind
But how does it know not to number the top no-toc, and start level one at its children?
magic?
As normally that would end up as 0.1 as the first child
i don't understand the problem you're trying to solve :-)
Oh, just trying not to remove features inherieted from the PP, and not wanting to add magic
well so long as it doesn't change, i don't really mind either way
the output, i mean
Hixie: But if we just go with that, which proibably works in any case for everyone who uses it, can you add no-num no-toc to the hgroup in the whatwg header?
Hixie: And to the h1 in the w3c header?
gsnedders: sure
Andrey Kosyakov. Web Inspector: display list of active workers & support debugging with fake workers. https://bugs.w… http://a.gd/wk55771
that sounds pretty cool
wonders if IE does the isindex magic if there's a valueless <input type=image> before the <input name=isindex>
hsivonen, I can test it for you if you have a test page
if you don't have IE available yourself
hsivonen must have IE now
Lachy: btw, where you been man
Lachy: seems like you've not been around on #whatwg so much lately
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/398
looks like Firefox 3.5 submits x and y in that case
looks like I was worried about dead code
MikeSmith, I've been really busy for the past few weeks doing Carakan QA, getting ready for shipping 10.50. And since then, I've mostly just been taking a break from HTMLWG stuff
hsivonen, in IE, if I enter "test" into the input and press enter, it just submits "test". If I click the image, it also submits the x and y coords.
Lachy: thanks
interesting. Last week Google Search cached pages used term, but now use nested b
Lachy: apparently Firefox counts the return as clicking type=image at 0,0 but IE doesn't
MikeSmith: We kidnapped Lachy and moved him to Sweden for a while.
MikeSmith: What he just said was really what we ordered him to say while we had him hostage
If that was the case, why would you admit it?
Perhaps what's really happened is that he has kidnapped you, and is ordering you to say the opposite in order to allay suspicions
gsnedders: I wonder if Lachy loves Sweden as much as he loves Norway
No. Norway is better
heh
well, at least Oslo is better than Linköping.
<snort>
At least it's easier to spell
well, nothing can compare to the wonders of Oslo
Which wonders are those?
Linköping isn't hard to spell, once you learn how to enter the ö character
it is hard to pronounce, though
it's not spelled in any sensible way for how it is pronounced.
Lachy: my pronunciation of it would suck - I'm thinking of it as 'link o ping'
Dashiva: the Stargate, just to name one highlight
Did they build that recently? I don't recall seeing it
<link ping="...">
Dashiva: it comes and goes
Hmm, not supported in HTML5 :-(
it's more like Lin-chirping, but, the 'ch' is softer sound than usual
gsnedders can probably tell you the IPA for it
Lachy: more like a 'sh' than a 'ch' perhaps?
"LPI" is the IPA for it, I'm pretty sure
sort of a cross between them, I think
MikeSmith: Do they have one of those cool giant spinny things like in Contact, or is it just a boring shimmering hole?
Philip`:  "shimmering hole" is more like it
shimmering like a puddle of something
with an oil slick of some kind on the surface
or at least you hope it's just oil and not something worse
seriously, the parts of Oslo where there are actual trees are wonderful
like the part the runs along the river that's next to the Opera office
not sure if this was shared yet http://mrdoob.com/lab/javascript/harmony
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-international/2010JanMar/0116.html
bravo Murakami-san
IE doesn't even support <rp>
Hah, fucking awesome. Hadn't seen his reply yet.
UAs ought to always support ruby, screw fallback
annevk: Make UAs ignore bracket-type characters inside <ruby>?
huh?
I mean that UAs should always support ruby rendering so authors do not have to care about <rp> or fallback for ruby
Old browsers exist, we can't do much about that
MikeSmith, you still there?
wonders whether the <cite> element really changed
annevk: yeah, here for a bit
HTML4 does not say much about it, though HTML5 does contradict a non-normative example that one of the editors of HTML4 thought was wrong
not really sure what to say about it
I think <cite> is changed at least as far as the fact that the example in the HTML4 spec is no longer conformant
the example that uses <cite> for a name
yeah
annevk: yeah, what you said
but there's no normative text that supports the example
agreed
but that's sort of not exceptional in the case of HTML4
I guess
I think there are other instances of the examples having resulted in bad practices that the spec did not normatively describe
so I guess we could say it's a change to existing practices that the HTML4 spec implicitly encouraged
or some such
I do think Jeremy is right to say that users should be alerted to this as being a more explicit restriction in HTML5
mkay
annevk: I thought IE did support <rp> when I tested it
though IE8 beta in IE8-mode had regressions
ok, it's not listed on msdn...
guess I shouldn't rely on that
Reading MSDN is never quite an adequate substitute for testing
tests IE8
annevk: It does indeed hide <rp>
(in IE8 mode and in quirks mode)

hey,can i change the letter spacing in canvas?
No
except by doing fillText("H e l l o") etc
ok :)
ok

no problem though

shame :s

the text isnt dynamic so no problem
gsnedders: I guess it counts as more dorsal compared to sv-SE.
gsnedders: it's more like 'ch' in English "check"
mut: I think the idea is that there should eventually be a drawHTMLElement() function, rather than putting more and more of CSS into custom canvas drawing functions
ok
ok yea that makes sense
hmm

one scaled up, one scaled down

only the smaller one shows
any idea?
Using excanvas in IE?
yea

other than having an idea that it often doesn't work
so I wouldn't be surprised by it breaking :-)
all im doing is ctx = smallcanvas; drawCanvas(); ctx = largeCanvas; drawCanvas
so if it works on the small on, surely.....?
heh
shrugs
mabe im putting too much faith into logic
hmmm
seems like excanvas dosentsupport multiple canvases
That seems odd
yea

because maybe some of them still reveal bugs

yeah
